item.title: disable cache in chrome during development
item.description:
I have encountered some very strange problems when develop a clojure web application. I changed the source file, and rename a namespace to another name, and figwheel re-compiled successfully.

The file should be changed, but I donot know why chrome still cached the old version of that file, which required for an old namespace which is now has disappeared. I have digged into this problem for hours, and finally find that is just caused by Chrome… That feels so bad!

Always toggle on the option ‘Disable cache(when dev tool is open)’, that will save you.

item.title: web history manipulation
item.description:
In the html4 standard, we can use window.location to programmatically change the url and navigate somewhere.

html5 new web api

The html5 bring a new web api web.history,

google closure library

The google closure library has capsulated a goog.History and goog.history.Html5History object for their native web api.

goog.History

The goog.History will listen for the hashchange event, and will trigger a goog.historyEvent we can listen to. The historyEvent has a token property which represents the current history.

goog.history.Html5History

The goog.history.Html5History will listen both for popstate and hashchange event, and do the same with goog.History.

There are some differences between

usage in clojurescript when making a SPA

use History

Since the History object take advantage of the hash tag #, you can keep all the href property link tag <a> unmodified, as click on them does not cause a new request at all. This will make things got some easier.

The structure of code will be:

The data flow is like:

  • my-component clicked, url(hash #) changed, fire hashchange event
  • history object fired a navigate event(since it listen for that event)
  • secretary dispatch a route to update the view

From above you can see the only extra effort you should make is to add an event listener for a new History object.

The disadvantage

The url with # can be marked as bookmark and can be used as a normal url to manully put in the browser address bar, but they can not be crawed by search engines like Google. That is why Google suggest to use the new history.pushState() to replace the location.hash.

use Html5History

To use the new api, we need do some extra work.

Firstly, we need to add event handler for <a> tag:

The getToken method of html5History object seems not work correctly when we click the back or forward button of the browser. So we need an helper function to get current token:

The data flow will be:

  • click trigger .setToken on history object
  • use history.pushState to change url
  • history fire a navigate event
  • secretary dispatch route to update the view

You need do more work than use the traditional hash history.

  • change the <a> to your customized link component
  • manually change the url

Conclusion

If we are using the same code to make a mobile app, then we can just directly use a path state to maintain current page state and keep the url untouched (despite in fact there is no visible url). But as a web app, we need connect the url with different app state, i.e. app views, thus a listener for a history navigate event will be neccesary. The history itself will listen the native web event popstate and hashchange when url changed.

The three conditions when url changed:

  • manually edit in the browser address bar
  • pushed back or forward button
  • click on a hyperlink

For the first condition, the browser will always make a new request, that is not in the consideration of the client side (that will be in the scope of routes defination at server).

For the second condition, the browser will never make a new request, and native web event will be triggered.

For the third one, there are two additional situations: if the href begins with #, the navigation will stay in current document, and can be listened; If it is a new location, you should add an event handler to prevent default behaviour since it will make a new request by default, and dispatch a customized handler.

item.title: use html5history and secretary to make SPA
item.description:
In javascript world, the React framework has the react-router library to wrap hashHistory or browserHistory to manipulate browser url. While in clojure, you may need to use the closure library from google to do it.

what you will use

  • secretary: a client route library for clojurescript
  • compojure: route library at server side for clojure
  • closure: a powerful, low-level JavaScript library designed for building complex and scalable web applications

route at server side

Traditionally you will have a '*' route placed at the end of all your routes to give a 404 not found, but in a SPA, you will do that at client side. The routes will be something like( use ring):

The request other than the urls you will show in your browser should be placed firstly, and the last one matches everything else, and send users the home-page of your app.

Important: Be sure to place the wild card route at the end and response your app apge.

route at client side

At client side, we can use secretary to set the routes:

when you want to change the route programmatically, use (secretary/dispatch! "/route" ).

add url listener

We use the new html5 api, and the corresponding object in google closure library is Html5History. The back button of browser and manually set the url using web api will fire a ` HistoryEventType/NAVIGATE` event, we can add an event listener to this event:

The event fired by code and back button have a little difference. Navigate event fired by back button does not have the .token property, so you can not get current url by the event. You will need make a new function to get current url:

set the link click handler

The default behaviour of a hyperlink will cause the browser to make a new request, so we add a click listener:

Now when you clicked this link, a navigate event is fired without a new request.

Done

Now the code will work like below:

  • You clicked a link or back button or forward button
  • A navigate event is fired and browser url is changed
  • Current url is got and dispatched by secretary
  • Page is re-rendered according the hooks by secretary/defroute

The old history manipulation method

The global window has a location property, which is like this:

The hash is used to mark a position in current document, and set this property will not cause a page reload. The pathname is the current relative url, and by directly change it or by location.assign('aNewPath'), a new request is sent and the page is reload.

So, the History object in google closure library use this property to manipulte url and keep staying in current page.

The Html5History object use the new web api window.history to do same job, since it directly change the url showed in browser address bar, it does not need a hash tag.
